review: Déjà le jeu lance le launcher d'ubisoft, ça c'est déjà un défaut. Ensuite le menu se lance dans mon dos, et c'est pareil dans le jeu, le menu se lance toujours au même endroit, ce qui fait que quand on tourne sur soi, on doit chercher parce que le jeu n'est pas capable d'afficher ce menu devant nos yeux. Ensuite le déplacement se fait uniquement avec la tête, ce qui est rapidement douloureux pour le cou, j'ai joué 24 minutes, j'ai déjà mal parce que chez Ubisoft ils n'ont pas l'air de savoir que le casque a un poids, en plus pour aller à la verticale vers le haut, il faut lever la tête à fond, ce qui est déjà pénible à faire avec un casque mais étant donné que je joue assis, j'ai le dossier de mon siège derrière la tête donc je ne peux pas lever la tête aussi haut. On ne peut pas regarder sur les côtés du fait, puisque notre mouvement suit notre tête. Et on ne voit pas à travers les yeux de l'aigle, mais on dirait une caméra placé sur son dos et donc on voit l'aigle sur tout le bas de la vision. Ensuite il y a un effet tunnel qui se met autour de la vision à certains moments, c'est déjà désagréable en soi mais ils se sont bien loupés parce que cet effet se place non pas à la périphérie de la vision mais autour de chaque lentille et donc on se retrouve avec une tache noire sur les côté du nez. Graphiquement c'est vraiment pas beau. Et en plus le peu que j'ai vu du jeu n'a pas l'air très intéressant, passer dans des cercles et ramasser des plumes, c'est un jeu à patounes (pour ceux qui ont la ref).

review: For an early VR game this is pretty good.  It has decent content and is an actual game rather than a tech demo.  The main issue is that since it's an Ubisoft game you have to use their launcher.  All this really does is make you wait while the launcher loads or updates, but often by the time it's done you no longer want to play and have moved on to something else.  In fact you may not even start the game at all because of this.  Why wait for this game to start when you have other possibly better options that you can just jump straight into?  Still recommended when on sale but just be aware of the launcher.

review:
そーらを自由にっ、とーびたーいなー！
はい、Eagle Flight！

無線環境でプレイ。
プレイアブルキャラクターは常に前進し続けていて、首の向きを上下、あるいは左右に「傾ける」事で旋回する。
操作をする上で左右を向く必要はない。
ただ、タイムアタック場面では正直自分が進行方向を向いたほうが、圧倒的に旋回性能は高い。

視界内には自身の嘴が映っており、多少の酔い止め効果になっているように思える。
ただゲームを終了した後、まるで目が回っているかのような独特の酔いがある。
リアルに戻って首を左右に傾けると、視界がぐにゃぐにゃする。

review:
Bell'idea, realizzazione terribile.
Prima di tutto per giocarci bisogna avere il client UPlay. Metti una cosa in vendita su Steam? La fai giocare su Steam. Non esiste che devo scaricarmi il tuo client, aggiornarlo e configurarlo per giocare. Se non vuoi che parta su steam te lo tieni sul tuo client e lo fai funzionare solo lì.

Il gioco poi ha una serie di problemi che impediscono la vera immersione dell'utente.

Partiamo dalle ali: voglio muoverle. Che significa che devo stare fermo? Cioè, sono un'aquila e mi fai fare la bella statuina? Non ha nessun senso, mi dai da premere DUE BOTTONI per andare più veloce o più lento? Cosa cambia da un simulatore di guida di aeroplani? Ci rendiamo conto che è una follia? Ho comprato un gioco per fare l'aquila, voglio fare l'aquila, fammi sbattere le ali! Soprattutto perché poi quando vedo gli altri volatili mi tracci pure le linee blu o rosse che partono dalla punta delle loro ali e fai vedere come si muovono, mi prendi in giro?! Mi fai vedere una cosa che sarebbe figo fare e non me la fai fare?

La visuale: bello il becco e le piume sopra eh, però mi piacerebbe anche vederci mentre volo. Quando giro mi piacerebbe che la visuale non si oscurasse di lato completamente a caso, cosa che per altro incentiva a girare la testa invece di inclinarla. Però se lo faccio mi fai comparire il messaggio davanti agli occhi "sarebbe meglio se girassi la testa". Anche qui, mi prendete in giro? Devo immergermi e mi fai comparire scritte a mezz'aria? Ancora peggio: appena per un istante perdo di vista l'obiettivo mi fai comparire una freccia fatta malissimo che me lo indica. Devo perdere la concentrazione per guardare la freccia, capire in che direzione sta puntando (non facile visto com'è fatta male) e poi seguirla, nel frattempo mi sono schiantato quattro volte.

Il volo: questo sarebbe anche carino, ma dopo 5 minuti è già noioso. Giri la testa, la inclini, premi due pulsanti, fine. Seriamente piuttosto uno si compra un simulatore di aerei. Pensavo che un gioco dove sei un'aquila ti offrisse qualcosa di più. Anche la grafica è pessima, non dico che volevo un assassin's creed, ma almeno che gli animali fossero composti da più di 2 poligoni. Ci ho messo 3 secondi a capire che stavo guardando un lupo e 5 per le giraffe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007813619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1637953056}
review:
I don't really mean to put a thumbs down on this game but I also don't want to recommend it.

First off, bad impression when the headset went unresponsive during first startup. I took the headset off to troubleshoot and found that the ubisoft launcher had popped up asking for UAC. I rejected its request twice, then it finally displayed a message in the headset, telling me to take it off to follow the ubisoft instructions on my pc monitor.. Great, could've shown me that earler.

After hooking up my game to the ubisoft account, I'm told to exit the game. Ok, I quit the game and start looking for the button to start it again.. Oh wait, quitting the game actually STARTS the game. Weird!

Well, now I can finally start flying like an eagle! Awesome view! Smooth experience.. And I'm nautious..

There are so many weird effects going on with the vision. There's blurring, there's darkening and weird distortions... All meant to alleviate motion sickness (I guess?). You can't turn these effects off, and they are making me very uncomfortable and nautious.

So yes, It seems like a neat game, but I'm having a hard time enjoying it because I keep focusing on the unstable vision and have to take frequent breaks. I have decent vr-legs but this made me motion sick pretty fast.

Get it on sale if you're curious, but don't expect a trouble free experience. I'll go look for mods or something to disable the vision effects, perhaps I can give the game another chance.

review:
A l'origine, j'étais optimiste et vraiment heureux de voir qu'Ubisoft s'est enfin dans la technologie VR.

Un jeu magnifique, qui promet beaucoup, un réel plaisir de pouvoir visiter Paris avec les yeux d'un aigle.
Malheureusement, je me suis vite retrouvé avec un message au milieu de l'écran qui dit :
"Il est plus confortable d'incliner la tête que de la tourner"...

LE détail qui vient foutre en l'air, toute la beauté du jeu...

Faut savoir qu'un être humain aime bien TOURNER LA TETE pour ADMIRER LE PAYSAGE, surtout quand on a l'opportunité de voir un paysage à travers les yeux d'un aigle !
On est pas née avec une minerve à la place de la nuque, et on est pas des crétins non plus...
Pas besoin de nous coller ce message au milieu de l'écran constamment, on sait lire !

Le système est bien conçu, tout est parfait, seul ce message vient gâcher tout le jeu et le plaisir qu'on a de visiter Paris à vol d'oiseau.

C'est quand même triste de voir que les seuls jeux qui vaillent la peine en VR sont des portages de Bethesda...

Vous testez vos jeu ???
Si vraiment vous arrivez pas, embauchez moi, mais arrêter de nous donner l'espoir de jouer un jeu vraiment sympa, et de tout nous détruire à cause d'une phrase à la con que PERSONNE n'a eu idée de supprimer...

Enlevez cette phrase qui nous tue tout le plaisir de jouer, et vous aurez des encouragements de ma part, ainsi qu'une bonne appréciation...

En attendant je ne peux que conseiller aux gens de passer leur chemin et de ne surtout pas dépenser d'argent la-dedans...

C'est dommage, parce que le jeu en lui-même donne vraiment envie d'y passer du temps... une envie vite avortée, à cause de cette stupide phrase qui persiste juste devant notre née.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200647458', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1617673675}
review:
as much as i want to recommend this game i just cant as a full product, but there is still some stuff i like about it. 

so first off, multiplayer is dead, with the game basically being abandoned and you will most likely not be able to find a game unless you organize a group to get on and play. secondly (at least in what i played of the story) the story doesn't really keep your interest outside of the tutorial for the extremely simple controls. and lastly, the vignette around the some of the screen can be bothersome, but it really will depend on the person.

now i do have a few good things to say about this

firstly, this is one of those games i would describe as using VR to truly transport you to another world, and it does a pretty good job of immersing you. secondly, the controls are so simple that outside of the menus (and the rare chance you find a multiplayer game) you can effectively play this without controllers as all the turning and movement is done with that head your hmd is attached to. third (tbh best reason to get this) is the free flight mode, free flight mode is genuinely great for de-stressing and is honestly what i saw this game as back even before i got my quest, it is legitimately one of my go to games outside of VRchat for claiming down.

final verdict-
if your looking for a game that's still being actively worked on and is more of a complete package, this is probably not the title for you.... but if your looking for something to sit back and relax after a stressful day and you see it on sale, i highly recommend it for the free flight mode

as a whole- 5/10
if your just interested in free flight- 8/10

review:
Eagle Flight spełnia marzenia o lataniu. Nie jest to jednak latanie majestatycznie niczym motyl, a dynamiczne, szybkie z wymijaniem przeszkód tak blisko, że między mną a przeszkodą nie wciśnie się kartki papieru. Radość z beztroskiego śmigania między budynkami lub zebrami jest niesamowita. Adrenalina pompuje się cały czas, gdy spadając pionowo w dół nagle odchylamy głowę w tył by zmienić kurs lotu unosząc się centymetry nad ziemią. Wow...

Gra nie ma większego celu. Latamy po opuszczonym Paryżu i przeżywamy ptasie życie zbierając pióra, jedząc ryby i odstraszając sępy i inne dziadostwa chcące zagrozić nam lub naszemu partnerowi. I tu ciekawa sprawa, bo gra ma coś co można nazwać systemem walki. Dysponujemy tak głośnym krzykiem, które zabija przeciwnika. Jest to dziwne, ale moim zdaniem lepsze niż salwa piór wystrzeliwana ze skrzydeł. A jako, że grę robił Ubisoft to gra jest obsiana znajdźkami i zadaniami, ale i bez tego zupełnie bez celu lata się bardzo przyjemnie.

Ciekawe jest to, że mimo dynamicznego ruchu i grania na siedząco nie spotkały mnie większe nudności. Dopiero po dłuższym graniu powoli zaczynała mnie boleć głowa. Oprócz tego gra ma dwie wady. Konieczność Uplaya (czy jak to się tam teraz nazywa) i brzydota. Gra jest po prostu brzydka. Otoczenia nie zachwycają, inne zwierzęta hasające po mieście też. Zwykle jednak lecimy na tyle szybko, że nie zwraca się na to uwagi, jednak na podziwianie widoków nie ma co liczyć. Brakuje mi niestety możliwości wykonywania akrobacji. Czasem chciałbym się obrócić o 90 stopni i przelecieć pionowo przez ciasny korytarz, niestety na to gra nie pozwala. Nie da się też wykonywać akrobacji, więc wszelkie beczki i inne cyrkowe sztuczki nie wchodzą w grę.

Krótko mówiąc. Jeśli tak jak ja skrycie marzycie o lataniu, to bierzcie śmiało i szybujcie.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083708122', 'num_games_owned': 4992, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1614226302}
review:
I avoided this game for awhile due to the all mixed reviews and generally that doesn't bode well for a 2016 VR game in 2021.   I picked this game up in a VR bundle and gave it a shot and had I known it was this good and ran this well on an Index, I would have paid full price long ago.  There's lots of neg reviews about the 'tilt' help message that appears on-screen but I've yet to see it.  Controls don't matter much since everything except speed controls are handled via head turns / tilts.  I didn't have any problems linking this to the Ubi store and it runs like a charm whenever I've tried it.  I haven't put much time in it yet but I can already tell this is welcome addition to the library and I wanted to try and offset the other less favorable reviews I'd seen that kept me away from the game for so long.   The un-configurable vignette-when-turning settings aren't a desirable inclusion but they aren't obnoxious enough to keep me from liking the game.  

Flying through Paris at top speed while divebombing zebras as they run through the streets is something that has to be experienced.  But you can also just smash your beak into the side of a building at top speed to really capture the essence of being a bird in peak form.   The game even gives a tasty wet smack sound effect to indicate just how much of your birdness is now on the outside of the Louvre.


edit: i played this for a few hours more and it's even better than I realized when I wrote the review but definitely turn off the vignette blinders in the config file (first google result works).  Why the devs didn't make this a menu option is absolutely insane but the game is even more amazing with that turned off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007453418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1609946845}
review:
C'est de la m.e.r.d.e – Eagle FLIGHT – Une bonne m.e.r.d.e bien empaquetée

Bon déjà j’aime pas Paris.
Ça commence mal. Après j’apprends que ce jeu était vendu 40€ à sa sortie.
"Ouaaf, ils ont du envoyé du pâté"
Mais, acheté en promo a 4€.
Humm ça commence à sentir la m.er.d.e mais bon, aller y a plein de jeu à ce prix qui sont super classe.

Aaaah Paris, ces immeubles, la tour Effel, le sacré cœur, c’est vrais que quand t’as la putin de capacité d’être un aigle t’as une furieuse envie de venir te faire c.h.i.e.r dans une ville et ses égouts.

On enchaine les vols dans un Paris verdoyant libéré de ses humains. On s e.n.m.e.r.d.e avec une musique ,certes que j’apprécie, mais beaucoup trop épique pour une chasse à la c.o.n de plumes planquées dans des décors aussi travaillés qu’un Minecraft mal dégrossi.
On vole en toute liberté dans la peau d'un aigle dans une carte aussi grande qu un timbre-poste
Car oui, le jeu se limite uniquement à Paris.
M.e.r.d.e un peu de classe, des vols dans la montagne avec des paysages grandiose, ca vous aurait fait mal au c.u.l d y penser ? 
Les sensations sont molles et là je pense qu il faut parler du Gameplay

author: {'steamid': '76561198006834106', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1610407869}
review:
Замечательная игра, одна из лучших для VR. Однако наделена двумя крупными минусами:
1. Иногда не запускается. Это всегда или почти всегда решаемо, но такого, тем не менее, быть не должно вообще.
2. Без перерыва выдает подсказку о том, что нужно «наклонить голову, чтобы повернуть» – неважно при этом, сколько часов вы уже отыграли и сколько раз уже продемонстрировали, что знаете, как поворачивать. Подсказка закрывает половину экрана и мешает летать, что особенно бесит во время гонок по сложным маршрутам. Это форменное безобразие, и Ubisoft просили исправить эту проблему с момента выхода игры. 2021-й, проблема до сих пор не решена, на игру, очевидно, давно махнули рукой. (Подсказку можно убрать клавишей grip, но она все равно будет всплывать вновь и вновь.)

Если же игру запустить удастся и вы приноровитесь быстро убирать подсказку, то получите изумительный симулятор полета. Лучший на сегодняшний день. Управление головой – очень четкое и удобное, тошнит намного меньше, чем в других играх, управляемых руками, а спустя несколько дней и вовсе тошнить перестает (таков мой опыт, по крайней мере). Гонки бывают простые и очень сложные, но всегда увлекательные, проходить все заезды на три звезды – сплошное удовольствие. Просто летать – тоже удовольствие. Очень жаль, что Ubisoft так и не удосужились исправить всего два бага, являющихся источником большинства негативных отзывов.

review:
My feelings on this game are like the current overall reviews: mixed.

This is an early VR title and it shows. In 2016 people say this felt like one of the few "actual games" while the rest were just "demos". I got this game in 2018 with my first headset after I played it a bit on the PS4.  And while yes there is a story and a campaign, me and a lot of other players (see global achievement statistics) cannot bring themselves to finish this. It is very repetitive and can be frustrating at times too.
It is clearly designed with gamepads in mind (after all it was one of the early PSVR games). So it just maps the buttons to your motion controllers but gives touchpad and back button the confusing names of LB and LP... Your motion controllers are never visible in-game. But you do need them or a gamepad.

Now it is a nice first attempt at a VR game by traditional game developers and certainly of historical value in the timeline of VR development. But I wouldn't recommend this game to you. Now it's 2020 and you can play Half-Life Alyx! And so many other great modern games! Please check these out instead.
I revisited this game today and just saw how far games have come already.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997856496', 'num_games_owned': 734, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1585402442}
review:
A sa sortie, j'avais très envie de tester Eagle Flight, mais je n'étais pas équipé en VR.
Aujourd'hui, en 2020, je teste ce jeu, et il est terriblement décevant.

TROIS GROS POINTS NÉGATIFS :

[b] 1) Le contenu est inexistant et le gameplay répétitif. [/b]

Dans Eagle Flight, la seule chose qu'on puisse faire c'est voler PLUS ou MOINS vite, et tourner à gauche, ou à droite.

Point final.

Avec de telles restrictions, difficile d'offrir du gameplay intéressant. L'essentiel du jeu se résume donc à des courses. Il suffira de diriger son regard vers des points de passage et de les atteindre le plus vite possible. 
Ces points de passage seront parfois des anneaux, des plumes, des poissons... Mais le principe restera toujours le même.
Le gameplay est donc terriblement pauvre, et le contenu tout autant puisqu'il n'y a jamais rien de nouveau.

[b] 2) Les graphismes sont datés [/b]

Quoi qu'on en dise, il faut reconnaître que graphiquement Eagle Flight est non seulement pas terrible, mais surtout plutôt moche.
On a plus l'impression d'être dans un jeu pour smartphone que sur un jeu PC.
Certains jeux arrivent à avoir un style intéressant malgré un rendu qui n'est pas réaliste, pour Eagle Flight là encore c'est râté :
C'est simplement daté, simpliste, bâclé, et très moche.

Je m'attendais à des graphismes un peu cartoon, avec beaucoup plus de détails. Mais ce n'est pas le cas.

[b] 3) La VR n'est pas à la hauteur [/b]

Curieusement, pour un jeu exclusivement VR je m'attendais à quelque chose de bien plus immersif. En mettant de côté l'aspect graphique pas top du tout, le rendu en VR est assez plat.
L'impression de profondeur, de hauteur, de 3D... C'est très léger.

Il ne faut donc pas s'attendre à avoir le vertige, ou avoir le coeur qui bat avec la vitesse. L'immersion est proche de zéro.



Pour le moment je retiens seulement 2 points positifs de ce jeu :

[b] 1) Sympathique pour tuer le temps 5 minutes [/b]

Les missions, défis, et tout le restent ne prennent pas plus de 5 minutes. Parfait pour une petite pause VR sans se prendre la tête.

[b] 2) Le jeu devrait tourner parfaitement sur n'importe quelle machine [/b]

Probablement un des rares jeux PC VR qui ne demandera pas une machine de guerre. Ca peut plaire à certains.







En résumé : Un jeu qui est aussi divertissant et qui se consomme de la même manière qu'un jeu mobile à 3€.
En toute honnêteté, un prix de 2€ ou 3€ me parait être correct. Pas plus.
Cet achat peut être un bon moyen de faire tester un jeu VR à quelqu'un qui n'a jamais joué à un jeu vidéo puisqu'il n'y a pas grand chose à faire. A voir...

A noter : le jeu utilise uPlay. Il faudra donc se créer un compte Ubisoft. Pour certains cela pose problème. Installez d'abord uPlay avant d'acheter le jeu, on ne sait jamais.

A noter également : Malgré le fait que je débloque les succès dans le jeu d'après uPlay, ils ne se débloquent pas sur Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139344280', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1565197275}
review:
[h1]Taumelnd über Paris[/h1]
Im Federkleid eines majestätischen Adlers über die Dächer von Paris dem Sonnenuntergang entgegenfliegen - und das in der virtuellen Realität! Eagle Flight klingt auf dem Papier nach einem sehr stimmigen Konzept und gehörte auch zu einer kleinen Zahl an VR-Titeln, die mir schon vor dem Kauf der entsprechenden Hardware ins Auge gesprungen sind. Nach knapp vier Stunden Spielzeit und dem Abschluss der Rahmenhandlung blicke ich mit gemischten Gefühlen auf das Erlebnis zurück.
Definitiv erfüllt haben sich meine Hoffnungen hinsichtlich der Optik und der Atmosphäre. Das postakopalyptische und langsam von der Natur und den Tieren zurückeroberte Paris ist in einem stimmigen Stil gehalten. Gemessen an der respektablen Größe der Spielwelt kann sich auch der Detailgrad durchaus sehen lassen, insbesondere bei der Gestaltung markanter Bauwerke. Für viel Atmosphäre sorgen aber besonders die geschmacksvolle Farbgebung, die tolle und variantenreiche Lichstimmung und der cineastische Soundtrack. Keine großen Erwartungen sollte man allerdings hinsichtlich der Story von Eagle Flight haben. Die erzählt den Verlauf eines Vogellebens und dient trotz stimmiger deutscher Erzählerstimme lediglich als roter Faden für das Gameplay.

[b]Eine Sache des Gefühls[/b] 
Apropos Gameplay: Die Hauptaufgaben unterteilen sich im Wesentlichen in drei verschiedene Typen. Zum einen wären da Flüge auf Zeit in den Höhen und durch den (Stadt-)Dschungel der französischen Hauptstadt. Außerdem gibt es Hindernisflüge durch die engen Schächte der Pariser U-Bahn und Kämpfe gegen andere Vögel. Die Flüge durch die obligatorischen Kreise in der Luft sind gut choreographiert und auch die Auseinandersetzungen mit anderem flatternden Getier bieten dank verschiedenen Gegnertypen etwas Abwechslung. Insgesamt experimentieren die Entwickler von Ubisoft im Laufe der gut 20 Hauptmissionen aber kaum mit den Spielmechaniken, so dass sich die Flüge gegen Ende des Spiels nicht mehr ganz taufrisch anfühlen. Aufgrund der geringen Spielzeit geht das aber noch in Ordnung. 
In der Open World warten zudem noch einige Sammelgegenstände in Form von Federn und Fischen darauf, von uns schnabuliert zu werden. Außerdem gibt es besonders knifflige Herausforderungs-Flüge, die aber alle auf die bereits erwähnten Spielmechaniken setzen. Zudem gibt es die Möglichkeit, im Koop über Paris zu fliegen, sowie einen PvP-Multiplayermodus. Aufgrund einem Mangel an suchenden Spielern konnte ich den aber nicht ausprobieren.
Das alles mag bisher wie ein durchaus solides Spiel klingen, was Eagle Flight wahrscheinlich auch durchaus sein kann. Mein größter Kritikpunkt und auch der Grund, warum ich letztendlich einen Daumen nach unten vergebe, ist nämlich sehr subjektiv und betrifft die Steuerung. Mit dem Controller beschleunigen und bremsen wir uns nämlich lediglich, die restliche Navigation erfolgt durch Kopfbewegungen. Die Blickrichtung bestimmt die Flugrichtung, kräftigere Drehungen erfolgen durch das Neigen des Kopfes. Das klingt erstmal sehr simpel und intuitiv und steuert sich auch so - allerdings nicht für alle meine Sinne. Während ich mit Achterbahnsimulatoren oder dem Flug durch die Schwerelosigkeit ohne festen Boden unter mir keine großen Probleme habe, hat sich bei mir schon nach einer halben Stunde in Eagle Flight ein sehr unangenehmes Schwindelgefühl eingestellt. Gerade das Neigen für die Drehungen spielt sich zwar praktisch aber hat sich meinem Empfinden nach für das Gehirn einfach nicht richtig angefühlt. Nun ist das aber sicherlich von Spieler zu Spieler verschieden. Wer von solchen Beschwerden weitgehendst verschont bleibt und nicht an Nackensteifheit leidet, darf sich nämlich auf ein durchaus spielenswertes VR-Erlebnis freuen. Der Vollpreis ist angesichts des selbst in seiner Überschaubarkeit etwas aufgeblasenen Umfangs aber trotzdem recht hoch angesetzt.
Übrigens: Achievements lassen sich wohl nur freischalten, wenn man die Sprache in Steam (Rechtsklick auf das Spiel > Eigenschaften > Sprache) auf Englisch stellt. Ein vermeidbares Ärgernis! 

[i]Fazit[/i]
[h1]Eagle Flight ist ein atmosphärisches und hübsches VR-Erlebnis mit rasanten Flugeinlagen, die auf Dauer an fehlender Abwechslung und einer intuitiven aber äußerst unkomfortablen Steuerung leiden. Letzterer Kritikpunkt ist in Teilen jedoch nur subjektiv zu beurteilen.[/h1]

[i]Wertung[/i]
[h1]69[/h1]    
[i]Wenn dir mein Review gefallen hat, freue ich mich über eine Bewertung.[/i]

review:
Je n'aime pas du tout ce jeu à cause de la façon de gérer le vol de l'aigle.
Ce qui ne veut pas dire que ça ne peut pas plaire à d'autres.
 
J'adore tous les jeux de type mouvement dans l'espace que ce soit de la simu d'avions, du wingsuit comme dans "Rush VR" ou de mouvement à la spiderman comme dans "Windlands"
Le concept d'Eagle Flight est génial et j'avais très envie de tester ce jeu.

Ce qui est bien fait :
La possibilité de voler dans les souterrains (métro etc) à travers les bâtiments, sous les arbres et plein d'endroits cool dans le genre et le fait que l'histoire vous y emmène à travers des défis.

Ce qui ne m'a pas plût :

- La façon de contrôler le vol avec les mouvements de la tête (inclinaison pour tourner).
Ca ne sera peut-être pas un problème pour tout le monde mais pour moi c'est rédhibitoire.
Déjà c'est assez désagréable et fatiguant pour le cou, mais surtout, ne pas avoir la possibilité de regarder autour de soi sans changer de direction m'a fait perdre tout intérêt pour le jeu.
Vous êtes condamnés à regarder devant vous en permanence.
- aussi le bec et les plumes que vous voyez tout le temps ne sont pas très beaux et je n'ai pas vu d'option pour l'enlever.
- pas vu d'option non plus pour enlever le noir qui se met sur les côtés quand vous passez près d'objets pour limiter la nausée j'imagine mais c'est dommage car ça enlève le côté fun de passer dans un petit espace à toute vitesse.
Bref dommage de devoir choisir entre recommander ou non le jeu, j'aurais mis 3 étoiles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112797338', 'num_games_owned': 640, 'num_reviews': 276, 'playtime_forever': 1743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1726, 'last_played': 1563718011}
review:
Orły to jedne z najpiękniejszych, najsilniejszych i najniebezpieczniejszych ptaków zrodzonych przez matkę naturę. Posiadają potężne szpony, doskonały wzrok, a ich skrzydła rozpościerają się nawet na 2,5 metrów! Jednak te atuty są niczym, kiedy popatrzymy, jaką ryzykowną strategią dla życia jest bycie drapieżnikiem — takim jak orzeł bielik. Ubisoft pozwolił graczom przeżyć to na własnej skórze i dzięki technologii wirtualnej rzeczywistości stworzyli [b]Eagle Flight[/b] — zręcznościówkę koncentrującą się na orlim życiu.

[h1] FABUŁA [/h1]
[i]Śpijcie spokojnie, zestawienie bez większych spoilerów![/i]
Akcja gry toczy się w bliżej nieokreślonej przyszłości na terenie Paryża, który z nieznanego powodu został porzucony przez ludzi pięćdziesiąt lat temu. Stolica Francji nosi ślady mrocznej przeszłości, którą pochłania dzika roślinność i którą zadeptują najróżniejsze zwierzęta. Młody orzeł zaraz po wykluciu musi nauczyć się żyć w tym niebezpiecznym środowisku. Nauka latania i polowanie to dopiero początek, gdyż z czasem przyjdzie taki moment, że trzeba będzie znaleźć sobie partnerkę, założyć z nią gniazdo, aby nasi potomkowie mogli zamknąć nasz cykl i rozpocząć nowy.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1784891203
Tym szlachetnym ptakiem jesteśmy oczywiście my — to nam przyjdzie poznać nowe życie z czołowego miejsca. [b]Eagle Flight[/b] ma cholernie ogromny potencjał na świetną historię, ale niestety za bardzo skupiono się na mechanice i trybie zręcznościowym, przez co produkcja jest powtarzalna, nudna i bez większych fabularnych dopowiedzeń, nie licząc bardzo ładnego wstępu.

[h1] MECHANIKA/ROZGRYWKA [/h1]
Wole od razu zaznaczyć, bo różnie to bywa — nie będziemy machać kontrolerami, jak skrzydłami! Twórcy opracowali ciekawy system sterowania, oparty głównie na ruchach głową, która bardzo ładnie ogranicza możliwość wystąpienia choroby symulatorowej, czyli mdłości. Można więc bez problemu grać na siedząco, gdyż skręcanie zostało podporządkowane przechylaniu głowy w jedną, bądź w drugą stronę. Do tego dochodzi jeszcze szereg opcji, takich jak przyspieszanie lotu czy zwalnianie, ale one już zostały klasycznie przypisane do przycisków kontrolerów. I chociaż początkowo byłem zły, że nie ma tutaj machania skrzydłami, ten sposób sterowania okazał się nadspodziewanie intuicyjny i w zasadzie tylko przechylanie głowy wymaga nabrania pewnej wprawy, gdyż instynkt podpowiada, żeby ją obracać.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1784893339
Sama rozgrywka jest bardzo powtarzalna, a więc oczywiście też nudna. Kampania główna składa się z pięciu rozdziałów (składających się na kilka misji każdy), które skupiają się na ważnych punktach orientacyjnych Paryża: Notre-Dame, Luwrze, bazylice, panteonie i samej wieży Eiffla. Typów misji jest kilka, jednak każda naciska na zręczność i wykonywanie podniebnych akrobacji prostymi ruchami głowy. Raz będziemy musieli przelecieć przez wszystkie obręcze, drugim razem będziemy polować na ryby, a kolejnym razem będziemy musieli szybko przeciskać się przez ciasne tunele — i tak w kółko przez pięć rozdziałów, a jedyną zmienną będzie poziom trudności. Gdzieniegdzie wdajemy się też w powietrzne potyczki z wrogimi nam sępami lub innym drapieżnym ptactwem. Te starcia też trudno uznać za złożone batalie, ale podążanie za przeciwnikami i strzelanie w nich „wirami powietrza” to zabawa trochę bardziej rozbudowana, niż zwykłe orle manewry.

Produkcji na VR jest niewiele, a tych, które oferują jeszcze możliwość rozgrywki z innymi graczami, trzeba ze świecą szukać. W tym przypadku w batalii typu „Capture the Flag” może brać maksymalnie udział sześciu osób, szkoda tylko, że serwery świecą pustkami — ledwo co udało mi się wbić osiągnięcia związane z trybem wieloosobowym, a więcej niż gry było tutaj siedzenia i czekania na innych graczy. Jednakże ten mankament nie świadczy o znikomej popularności [b]Eagle Flight[/b], lecz o naprawdę małej popularności samej technologii wirtualnej rzeczywistości.

[h1] OPRAWA GRAFICZNA [/h1]
Chociaż pod względem rozgrywki [b]Eagle Flight[/b] jest monotonne i nudne, tak przepięknymi widokami trudno się nie zachwycać. Paryż obserwujemy najczęściej na tle zachodzącego słońca, ale będzie okazja przyjrzenia się mu po zmroku i w deszczu. To wszystko — mimo rysunkowej, mocno uproszczonej grafiki — cieszy oko. Jedynie co mnie boli, to brak animacji skrzydeł orła, w którego się wcielamy. Ciągle są rozłożone w jednej pozycji, jak gdyby były tylko elementem drętwego posągu.

W miarę dobrze wypada przy oryginalnym lektorze polski lektor, który idealnie tonuje zdania i zwraca uwagę na interpunkcję. Szkoda tylko, że został dograny zbyt cichutko, czego nawet ingerencja w ustawienia nie potrafi naprawić.

[b]Eagle Flight[/b] jest rozczarowującą produkcją, w której jedyną wartą uwagi rzeczą jest oprawa audiowizualna. Wszystko mógłby uratować lepiej poprowadzony tryb fabularny, który naprawdę zaczął się dobrze. Niestety obrano jednak inną drogę, która mało komu przypadnie do gustu. Poza tym największa atrakcja — jaką miał być tryb rozgrywki z innymi graczami — jest niegrywalny, ze względu na mały target graczy posiadających odpowiedni sprzęt do takiej produkcji. author: {'steamid': '76561197989833840', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1581580871}
review:
My wife bought this as she's not a gamer and she wanted to experience VR outside of things like Beatsaber and Pavlov, and she prefers seated experiences. I didn't think much of it at first assuming it would be just another VR "experience" with not much in the way of content. I'm happy that I was wrong, and I should've checked my judgements at the door. This is a great game, and it's really enjoyable to play all the way through to completion. 

The game is a concept that only works in VR. The control mechanism works well, and can be quite relaxing as you're just sitting there tilting your head to fly around Paris. Being a Ubisoft game, it has the polish you'd expect from a AAA studio. The world is is a good size compared to other VR only games, and there is plenty to do. Missions consist of collection quests, races, time trials, defend-and-escort, and others. There are unlockables and rankings for each mission and area, giving replayability and a hook to keep you wanting to improve. The game can be genuinely challenging at times, and the arcade like experience in the missions means it's easy to continually retry a mission to unlock full stars. Flying around and dodging buildings and trees gives you that VR rush that you got the first time you tried a roller-coaster sim. 

People complain about the head-tilting warnings, but if you actually listen to them, and tilt your head instead of turning it, the warnings don't pop up. Not to mention not turning your head relieves neck strain and gives you more nimble, precise control.

If you're a Linux user, I'm also happy to report that it runs fantastic in Proton once you learn the quirks of using it alongside Uplay.

I paid $25 for it, and at that price it's worth it. I don't think I'd pay the original $40, however. If you see it on sale for under $25, just buy it.

review:
一時間程プレイした結果の感想ですが、

[b] とても面白いです [/b]

このゲームは首で方向を決め、トリガーで速度を調節します。
とてもシンプルです。
感じ方は人それぞれかと思いますが、VR酔いをする方でも楽しく酔わずにできるかと思います。
また、VRゲームに多いバグも無く、とても完成されているゲームです。

下記、ネタバレをはさみます。

[spoiler] 主人公は鳥として空を飛び回り、色々な所をめぐり、勉強していきます。マップは五つほどあり、オンラインプレイも可能です。例えばミッションで地下鉄を高速で飛び回ったり、沢山の動物が住む所を見学していったりします。感覚としては自分で操作できる安全なジェットコースターに乗っているような感覚でした。魚を捕まえたり、羽を集めたりするちょっとした遊びみたいなものもありますので、やり込み性はとても高いと思います。 [/spoiler]

2000円を出しても決して後悔する事は無いと思いますが、プレイにはUplayアカウントが必要ですので作る必要があったりはします。

author: {'steamid': '76561198349907079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1553497416}
review:
首の傾きで旋回操作を行うので直感的に動けます。手での操作は加減速とメニューの決定ボタン程度の簡単操作。
自分は購入前はフリールックができればいいなと思っていましたが、加減速が自由にできるので、減速状態にしていればある程度は見回すこともできます。
急降下して急上昇、建物の間をすり抜けて飛んでいく、などなどフリーモードで飛んでるだけで楽しめます。

が、VRに弱い人はもとより、ある程度酔わない人であっても合わない人はいます。
酔いにくいように工夫がほどこされまくってますが、それでも首を傾けての旋回やスピード感で酔う人はいるようです。

ハイスピードで爽快感あるVRゲームに興味がある方は是非一度やってみることをお勧めします。

review:
Played for about an hour and it's a great game with one huge exception... the TILT YOUR HEAD notifications are very annoying. It appears right in the center of the screen, obscuring your vision. The only way to remove it is by tilting your head and make a hard turn. This issue is especially annoying when you only want to look around (there are a lot collectibles). The moment you start doing this, the TILT YOUR HEAD notification pops back up again.

You would think there's an option to remove the notifications in the settings... nope! It's not there. How such a basic feature managed to slip by QA is a mystery. If you search for this issue on Google, you'll see it's been a problem for quite some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970558615', 'num_games_owned': 3396, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1552200424}
review:
Wow, I wasn't expecting that.  
Okay, I've only played 20 minutes, and have only tried one 'mission', but that's not my wow.

My wow is this... I can't believe how well the head turn/twist controls work... flying around Paris actually fun... simply to do for the sake of doing it.  Um, hmmm... it's like being a bird.  That's the wow.    

I had one 'crash' (bird, not program) in 20 minutes.  Doesn't sound amazing, but once you start flying and it feels like flying... spot an tight arch... and easily fly through it... like a bird would.   Very cool.

Not sure about the 'game' aspect of this yet, but I do recommend to everyone to give this a try.  I will be sharing this experience with friends to try.   I simply feels natural to fly around like a bird.  Nice.

Without knowing the full game side of it, I can't recommend buying a full price.  But I would definitely recommend buying either on sale, or with possibility of refund, simply to give it a try and experience flying like a bird.   

Better than I expected.  One of those programs that couldn't exist without VR.  Try it.

review: Game is honestly ruined by the prompts to tilt your head. It's an interesting experience and I'm sure the story's great, but I had to quit after 15 minutes because if the game somehow detects you're not playing right, it will splash a prompt to tilt your head in the center of the screen for something like 30 seconds. The prompt is huge and completely takes you out of the game, you can't do anything to make it go away, and there's no way to disable it. It's the worst design decision I've seen in a VR game so far and I don't know how it made it through QC without somebody saying "hey maybe that prompt is a little much." If they wanted to disable turning with your head, they should have disabled it. It's like if you were playing a platformer, but every time you pushed one of the two identical jump buttons a prompt fills half the screen to tell you "real gamers press 2 to jump." If you can cope with the handholding or somehow find a way to keep the game from complaining at you, you might enjoy it.

review:
Never purchased back when this game was released because I dislike the FORCED Comfort mode.  Purchased years later and you know what?  It's actually not as bad as I was expecting...

The scenery is very nice.  Detailed future Paris overgrown with vegetation and wildlife.  Good sensation of speed.  The game was a brave move by Ubisoft.  Released at the height of the nausea hysteria but just as people were starting to rebel against it and demand comfort mode be made optional.  Thankfully VR gaming recovered from said nausea hysteria and we now have multiple options in games.

Would have been nice if Ubisoft had updated the game to allow for it to be disabled.
Also would have been nice if the horizon tilted as you turned... having the horizon locked is another forced comfort thing I'd rather not have since I and many others are perfectly able to handle 360 roles in flight sims with vomiting.

Gameplay is unusual.  Worth at look.  With the music and narration it feels like a David Attenborough bird program....

author: {'steamid': '76561197981801006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1600217199}
review:
Secondary drm is reason enough for me to recommend against a purchase, and my first-play frustration is still not the reason for giving the game a "no" (a soft no - it earned its "mixed" steam reviews status)

You must have Uplay (so why even sell the game on steam?) and getting steam and uplay to communicate was a bit of a hassle. The game launched and said to take off the headset and follow the on screen instructions (which inconveniently were not on screen). 
after fiddling for a little bit i eventually got it to play (isn't this supposed to be the job of the game developers, to make a game that works).

The game does have some merits. It is very nice looking, and the narration was pleasant. It has a reasonable story mode with tasks for you to complete such as fly through rings or collect feathers. It is called "eagle flight" so keep in mind the ground is lava. The neck controls i read a few complaints about, but it works well enough and i did like giving my hands a break.

As far as bird-games go, copoka (while shorter and not VR) was more pleasant to play and cheaper.
For VR going through rings and collectathon, i prefer mount wingsuit (which has a steeper learning curve, but overall was more fun).

my guess is that it started more as interactive art (it is a cool world they have set up) and then someone remembered it needed to be a game. And they did a decent job of adding some gamification, but it is these separate mini-games in the world and doesn't flow well making gameplay seem like a secondary concern.

Don't expect it to work out of the box, and don't pay full price. It had a price drop and i still waited for it to go on sale. I invested a bit of effort in getting it set up, and i'll keep it installed, and probably play again next time i want to play VR but don't want to break a sweat. Since the frustrating part is out of the way, i can relax more next time. It's not a bad game, but it's just not that great either. The best reason for not buying this game, is that there are other games you could buy (vr or otherwise). It is a real shame, because it could have been great.

Amazingly fun idea but spoiled by terrible control decisions right from the very start.  Let's start with the onerous login and account creation procedure that is completely unnecessary for offline play.

 Left Grip to select a menu option?  What's wrong with either trigger, or either grip, or virtually any button, most of which are unused?  

Then instructions appear on screen and won't go away, seemingly forever.  I get it, tilt my head to turn.  You can go away now.  No amount of random clicking on the controllers dismisses the message plastered directly in front of my face.  

Also tilting your head to turn is absolutely dizzying and vomit-inducing.

Every time I open the game I experience the same thing -- five minutes of amazement followed by increasing irritation at simple control decisions made incredibly poorly, followed by uninstalling the game.

review:
J'ai acheté ce jeu à 10€ en promo et je ne le regrette pas. Le jeu est très plaisant et agréable, mais c'est un peu répétitif à terme. Le multiplayer est 100% mort, donc même si on prend un vrai plaisir à voler et à se diriger, on ne peut pas y jouer trop longtemps d'affilée avant d'avoir envie de passer à autre chose.

Le jeu est un des plus réussis que j'ai pu tester sur mon Lenovo Explorer à ce jour, même si je manque peut-être de points de comparaison. J'adore vraiment la possibilité de diriger le vol très précisément avec des mouvements de tête, c'est aussi naturel que bluffant. Même si les contrôleurs ne sont pas utilisés (mais pad 360 obligatoire pour régler la vitesse), eh ben jouer assis, c'est sympa aussi finalement.

Le jeu peut se faire au calme, avec un vol pépère alternant entre obstacles et aires libres, ou il peut devenir bien speed si on va chercher les obstacles les plus pénibles. Ca reste globalement relaxant (corps au repos), avec des réflexes requis, mais pas d'effort physique.

Pour moi qui ait un faible pour les navions et les chtis piafs, c'est difficile de ne pas aimer ce jeu. Je le trouve un peu cher à 20 euros question de manque de variété, mais à 10 ça les vaut bien. La qualité de finition est tout à fait top, c'est aussi l'avantage de passer par un gros éditeur.

review:
This is a positive review, however I'll lead with the negatives - I'd like Ubisoft to consider them. 

1) Don't ask for a second registration system - throw that out. If I log into Steam and buy a game, it's daft to sticky tape another system on top. Focus on games, let Steam or something handle whatever Uplay does. Sorry, that's my view - it's a niggle and detractor.

2) Make it possible to remove annoying and repeating prompts to tilt the head - after a few minutes users get the idea and it's easy to crash with the prompts in the way. Whilst I'm on prompts, may be worth making other prompts a little easier to configure as subtler :).

A caution - 2 hours playing leaves the user with a peculiar system: tilt the head and the world moves! This is a neurological effect caused by an overadaption of the inner and the auditory nerve maybe? Shows that at 40 my brain still learns.

It's a great game, really engaging, intuitive and good fun. It's quite a challenge at times. It works very well for anyone who has wanted to fly. 

It's one of the earlier VR games yet somehow does not suffer by comparison with later games at all. 

At it's current price of £8 it's easily worth while.

Some reviewers don't like the eagle beak - perhaps it should be configurable but for me, I'm sorry but a bird of prey probably does have a view not so different to this. Current VR systems have a restrictive field of view anyway - if they ever get to be much wider, this game will be even more engaging.

You can be incredibly precise with the head turns and very quickly too. Much of the challenge in this game is flying fast and precise without knowing exactly what the next corner holds (see challenges like catacombs).

You get to explore Paris and you can waste a ton of time stunt flying for fun around the city without doing anything else. 

If you like the idea of flying, this is pretty damned good. 

You've seen my negatives - they're not making me return it, nope, will be using it a few hours a week easy for a while.

review:
Eagle Flight is actually just the second VR game I use and the first which makes the VR concept feel really useful.

The game consists of a "free flight" and a series of mini-games in a loose story: obstacle courses, air races and air combats very similar to war flight simulation games. It starts rather peacefully but if you want to continue the story there's no way around fighting crows, vultures, bats and the like. Not that I dislike any of these animals but the game needs some sort of enemies and aliens are not an option here. ;-) If you are one of the "hunters and gatherers" the gam can monopolise your time while you look for feathers and fishes to catch.

The navigation is very intuitive, actually the most intuitive way of controlling an airborne thing I know so far. That you have to tilt you head in order to steer left or right might sound strange at first but avoids you rotating around your axis during gameplay. (I wouldn't mind if there is a mode which allows this as I am sitting on a rotating chair anyway.) One thing I miss is the possibility to just land anywhere and take the time to look around, as any real eagle would do. You can only land on your nest, otherwise you are constantly flying. Strange enough, you cannot quit the game from the nest menu, only from the pause menu.

The graphics are slightly cartoonish, not too photo-realistic, but definitly atmospheric, so its a joy to fly over this large chunk of a Paris re-gained by nature. The game runs smoothly on my GeForce 1050 Ti, maybe exactly because the level of detail is not exaggerated.

I really love the game soundtrack  - exactly a fitting music, not distracting and definitely not boring with its pushing rhythems. Luckily it is available as MP3 album.

The reason I still do not recommend this game are the technical problems mainly resulting from Ubisoft requiring the installation of "Uplay". "Uplay", in short, is something similar to Steam, a fraud protection and game marketing platform. It took me one hour to get through the installation and account creation procedure and get the steam account connected to uplay. There's no real help, so this was quite an obstacle course!

So If you have a problem with creating YET ANOTHER account, agreeing to YET ANOTHER hair-raising EULA, installing YET ANOTHER copy protection software on your PC and giving away your personal data (like birth date) to YET ANOTHER company, then better avoid this and all other games of Ubisoft. Maybe Ubisoft will learn someday what [b]real[/b] Steam integration means.

What's worse, the whole combination of MS MixedReality, Steam VR, Uplay and "Eagle Flight" seems to be rather fragile. Often enough the game does not start correctly bringing up a strange message (known issue, see forum) or loading far beyond 100% without actually starting. If Uplay doesn't startup (f.e. because it updates itself) the game shows a screen telling you to press the "A" button to quit - but there's no such button on my controller.

Another minor issue is that during the missions you need to use an increasing number of controller keys. The game uses abbreviations for them but never tells you what these abbreviations mean. I had to figure out myself (e.g. LP=left pad, RT=right trigger, LG=left grip button). (Hint: The "Known issues" forum thread now contains a graphics showing the use of each key!) 

Then there is a bug which prevents your achievements to show up in Steam if you play in any other language than English. :-(

So its a really beautiful and genuine game but negated by Ubisoft with a problematic installation and start-up bugs. Will never buy another Ubisoft game unless it is fully integrated into Steam, not requiring Uplay any more.

review:
This game is let down very severely by just one point - it is not possible to turn off the eagle's head that is 'attached' to your view. I have been using HMDs since 2003 and very rarely get sick in VR. I note that the graphics quality and general smoothness of this game are great, so my best guess for the cause of my nausia is this attachment. 

To the devs / designers: I *strongly* suggest putting an option in the settings for turning off this potentially nausia inducing view of the eagle's head. I understand there is some research out there that claims such attachments actually reduce nausia, but in my experience they do quite the opposite. 

This *needs* to be a configurable preference before I can recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042873438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1533407560}
review:
Idee, Design und Story sind wunderschön. Die riesige detaillierte Stadt mit all ihren Möglichkeiten auch, selbst wenn ich auf einer 1080Ti, 32GB DDR4 und 6x5,00Ghz i7 nicht das Gefühl habe dass es flüssig läuft. Im Gegenteil, aber es gibt auch leider keine Grafikoptionen. 

Allerdings ist es unspielbar, da für manche Leute sehr wichtige Optionen fehlen.
Mir wird beim "Drehen durch Neigen" furchtbar schwindelig, deshalb drehe ich mich einfach in Echt. An sich kein Problem. Leider taucht dann eine Meldung direkt vor dem Gesicht auf dass man den Kopf neigen statt drehen soll "Weil es komfortabler ist" (Anmerkung: Nein danke, das ist subjektiv und darf ich als mündiger Erwachsener schon selber entscheiden), die geht auch nicht wieder weg wenn man sich nicht wieder nach "vorne" dreht. Total bescheuert, ein simpler Menüpunkt hätte das gelöst. Stattdessen zerstört diese simple Meldung das ganze Spiel.

Im Menü konnte man dann auch gleich den ganzen anderen Quatsch ausschalten, der da wäre:
-Komische Sicht des Adler-Kopfes weg, ich komme mir vor als würde man mir die beschränkte Sicht noch unnötig mit einem starren und hässlichem Rahmen einengen
-Komische Schwarzblenden weg, ich kenne den Sinn dahinter aber es sollte doch wenigstens optional ausschaltbar sein
-Das Drehen durch Neigen ganz ausschalten und den User sich einfach in echt drehen lassen, dabei dann auch keine Warnmeldungen mehr

Was mir sonst noch aufgefallen ist: Wenn man bremst, kommt immer die Animation als würde man bremsen, auch wenn man schon ganz langsam ist und nicht noch langsamer werden kann

Fixt das und ich kaufe mir das Spiel wieder. So gebe ich es zurück, laut dem Kommentarbereich ist das Problem wohl schon ewig bekannt und Ubisoft ist ignorant. Ich habe in meinem ganzen Leben zuvor noch nie ein Spiel zurückgeben müssen.

Ach ja, sich in Ubisofts "Steam" noch anmelden und dieses installieren zu müssen, obwohl ich es mir über Steam kaufe, ist an sich auch recht frustrierend gewesen.

review:
Reccommend on sale *only*. 10 bucks is a good price.

Within about an hour, you've seen everything Eagle Flight has to offer in terms of gameplay. You fly around by moving/tilting your head, and you accelerate/decelerate/shoot a basic projectile with your controller. 

With all that said, I won't be refunding Eagle Flight because I plan on playing more of it. What's there is solid enough to be enjoyable, and while what little variety there is wears thin quickly, the act of flying itself is compelling enough to keep coming back, even if it's just for short bursts.

I wouldn't pay any more than I did for it, though. Not much else there. It's also a god damn shame that the developers didn't implement a way to deactivate the FOV reduction - it is a legitimate dampener on the experience for a lot of people, and while I wasn't angry about it, I was very disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007223119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1527880182}
review:
Naja ist n Vogelflugsimulator mit netter aber recht simpler Grafik, was vielleicht für nicht ganz so leistungsfähige Rechner ganz gut ist.

Der Sound ist nicht nennenswert aber auch nicht schlecht, halt auch recht simpel auf das nötigste reduziert.

Dafür stimmt das Fluggefühl, ist jedoch tatsächlich durch das teilweise eingeschränkte Sichtfeld etwas gestört.

Die Herausforderungen reichen vom Flug durch Ringe über das Sammeln von Federn oder Fischen bis zum Luftgefecht mit anderen Vögeln. Dabei schaltet man immer schwerere Herausforderungen frei, bis man halt alles in der Perfektion seiner Wahl erledigt hat. Da das Spiel teilweise doch herausfordernd ist wird man dazu wohl 3 – 10+ Stunden benötigen je nach dem ob man Profi oder Noob ist.
Auch kann man im Multiplayermodus mit anderen Luftgefechte abhalten. (cool, wenn man eine bessere Internetanbindung wie ich hat. Ob der wirklich gut ist kann ich jedoch nicht sagen.)

Was das Spiel von einer Spitzenwertung meinerseits abhält sind die fehlenden frei wählbaren Spieloptionen, wie Komfortmode Anpassung, Grafikanpassung mit abwechslungsreicheren Texturen und eine bessere Kollisionsabfrage. Hatte aus meiner Sicht unfaire Kollisionen mit Objekten und das mehrmals an der gleichen Stelle. Hab dann die Herausforderung nur beenden können indem ich die Stelle so weiträumig wie möglich umflogen hab.

Trotz alle dem würde ich das Spiel ab einem 50% Discount empfehlen, weil es mir meistens höllisch viel Spaß macht ;)

review:
Let me first say that I've played this one both before on the PSVR and now and my laptop with SteamVR on Dell Visor WMR. Among all the VR games that I tried, it's the most relaxing one to me because of the smooth flying even when doing intense race challenges. It takes a little getting used to steering with head tilting rather than turning, but once you got the hang of it it's great. Main negative from my side is that mission variety isn't great. However the design of the city and the challenges is very beautiful.

Last but not least, I gotta say that experimenting with the relatively underpowered laptop with *only* a Radeon R7 M370, this game can still provide one of the best VR experiences with such a low-spec setup. I turned the resolution down manually in the SteamVR video settings and now it runs rather fluent as long as I don't turn too fast. Fortunately this game actually rewards slower, smoother turns, and the fact that the framerate isn't 100% all the time is barely noticeable. No VR nausea by the way; speaking to the careful design of this game.

review:
Casual game.  You get to fly though.

There is a very annoying game mechanic.  If you turn your head, this huge overlay covers a large portion of your vision and says "Tilting your head is more comfortable than turning it".  It stays up until you turn your head back to where the game thinks center is.  This popup is EXTREMELY UNCOMFORTABLE as you are constantly flying but suddenly have a big thing in your face.  Also, you have no idea where center is, because you're wearing a VR headset.  So you can't get rid of the damn thing until you admit defeat, let yourself crash, and walk in a circle until you find where it wants you to be looking.  It's ironic and obnoxious.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998056243', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 430, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1524929761}
review:
It can be fun for the first minutes....aside from the fact that the full price is a joke (50 euros?), there are two main problems with this game I guess:

- controls: you fly with your head, but you have to keep your head straight at 12 o'clock in your VR play area....if you turn your head in a direction that is not the front facing one, you get a prompt on screen, very invasive. But that's not that bad: you are bird, yet your head is tied to your wings apparently. You can't look at the ground while flying straight (guess what, it's what eagles do when they hunt for prey....), making everything less fun, more stiff, tiring, and also making looking for collectibles around the city a torture (the game makes collectible hunting one of the main features...)

- gameplay: too repetitive, and because of the reasons above, repeating something is really not the best idea.

PRO: scenery is nice, exploring can be fun.

Bought the game for 12 euros while on discount but still requested for a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994768182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1524236509}
review:
First of all, the game is basically wonderful.. unfortunately as far as I have seen it's also not playable because of a peculiar bit of stubbornness on the part of the developers.

There have clearly been requests for a long time to do something about the invasiveness of the 'Tilting your head is more comfortable' prompt.  It fills and obstructs your view, and doesn't go away .. in my experience at all, unless you go through the several seconds long procedure to pause and un-pause the game, and then returns several seconds later anyway.  The developers have apparently stubbornly refused to take any measures to mitigate the issue, with forum posts in various places for a long time and significant updates to the game in other areas since.

I have seen posts suggesting that this is because the game expects you to be seated, but as far as I have seen that does nothing to mitigate the issue.

Also, reliance on UPlay (and I hear also Denuvo).  For me it's not a dealbreaker but that's hardly a mark in it's favour.

Again, besides this one, unfortunately and effectively game-breaking issue, what I have been able to play has been wonderful.. but nonetheless, I have requested a refund.  If I ever find out the issue /has/ been rectified I'll buy it again and update my review, but I cannot recommend it for now.

review:
the best VR flying experience!
reminds me of assasins creed + nintendo pilotwings 64 + far cry primal

for those who dont know, flying is something many VR fans are excited about at first, sadly there just arent any good flying games because its very very hard to prevent people from getting motion sick. flying essentially means EVERYTHING around you is moving, and usually at a high speed, while your body constantly tells your brain its not moving at all. review:
Its cool and feels great flying around a city as a easgle but its lacking a lotin content. The main missions feel like side missions and i beat the game in 2.5 hours. The missions consist of flying through rings, air combat against other birds, and racing through under ground tunnels . with a 2 others like catching fish and feathers.The city is pretty good sized and you got some room to spread your wings and enjoy flying. Graphically it looks ok nothing special.

There is a story to it but its pretty lame. Controls are easy to ick up . You basically just face where you want to go and use the controller or your motion controls to eather speed up slow down, fire a screach attack , or put up ashield.

$40 is way to much for this game and if i had paid it i would have refunded the game. $15 is about what its worth tops and thats what i paid for it. I do have a lot of fun  just blazing through the city at break neck speed flying through tight areas trying not to crash. That is probably where i enjoy the game the most and why its worth picking up. 

If you want a agme where you can enjoy the feel of flight in VR then the game does a great job at it. unfortunitly it doesnt do much at any thing else. still i found it worth it just for that.

review:

唯一美中不足 的就是坐着玩玩久了连我这个FPS老玩家也会头晕。
我先缓一会儿去……

author: {'steamid': '76561198062871429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1518456320}
review:
Short version: This game gives me motion sickness... Bigtime. I was demoing VR to some house guests and this game also ends their experience due to sickness. 
On top of being nearly unplayable due to motion sickness, the game is just a gimmick. The gameplay isn't too compelling and the story is odd. If I could play for more than 20 minutes at a time (people who aren't used to VR can't last 5 minutes) then I'd probably free fly instead of playing the story. There's not much to do here. 

Longer version: To be clear, I can spend my whole day in VR in any other game without any motion sickness, and my rig is a i9 7900x with SLI dual GTX 1080 TI so it's not me or my rig that can't play VR, it's this game that makes me and everyone I show it to want to puke. 
Part of that is probably the control scheme, they want to make you tilt your head to turn, which generally leads to a disconnect in what you see and what your head is doing, which I think is where the motion sickness comes from. 
The other thing that causes severe motion sickness is some parts of the game (namely cutscenes) are 360 degree videos, where your head is snapped from one angle, so if you turn your head you're fine but if you move the video stays in the same place. Those videos are fine if you stay still but if you move an inch then you feel sick because your head moves and the image doesn't change. 
Generally the gameplay reminds me of the challenge levels in the old school Spyro games where you fly through rings or shoot enemies in an endless flight challenge. This game is much the same, it amounts to races against time where you collect things or fly through rings. 
Generally the look of the game is good, the soundtrack was compelling, and flying through the city was nifty. If the game didn't cause motion sickness, I would show all of my house guests the free fly mode, but would probably still find the story underwhelming. I kinda want to see if it gets interesting after chapter two... but I also don't want to feel this motion sickness again.

review:
Very disappointed.  I waited for this game to be on sale.  I finally decided to take a chance and buy it at $19.99 USD.  This is a $9.99 game at most.  Don't get me wrong, there is a lot of content here.  This version of Paris is a pretty big world to fly in, especially in comparison to other VR games.  

However, a lot of the gameplay is redundant.  Almost everything is a race.  That would be awesome if there were more twists and turns along the way or the environments looked amazing (tracks).  Unfortunately, there never is a sense of speed when flying.  Ubisoft seemed to have focused on making this game accessible for new VR players or people who experience nausea.  So a person like me, who is a VR veteran and has never experienced any nausea from day one, feels like they are flying in slow motion.  

Do races where you drive slow sound fun?  That's basically this game.  Even the "dog fights" in the air don't feel right.  There's no rush.  There's no adrenaline pumping.  Nothing.  Feels like you have kiddie gloves on the whole time.  On top of that, the graphics are way too cartoonish.  I would have preferred just a normal looking Paris.  This is like ghost town Paris with very cartoony graphics.  Even the bears, lions, giraffes ... they all look like something out of Saturday morning cartoons.  

So maybe this game would be fun for kids.  But for any serious gamer, this is a hard pass.  Try mount wingsuit instead.  Now that's a fun flying game in VR.  This, this is just sad.

Rating 4/10

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197979636722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1627412982}
review:
VRのゲームを10数個購入しわかったことは、
* 歩行移動は酔いやすい
* 解像度の関係で、ローポリなほうが画面が綺麗に見える
* 画面内に鼻が見えると酔いにくい
* 物理的に動ける範囲が狭いと色々辛い（ケーブルが足に絡むなど）
こんな感じですが、このゲームは全てがクリアされています。
一言で言うと、遊んでいて"疲れにくい"ですね。

鳥の視点で、フランスの街並みを飛び回るんですが、
大体の操作を首の動きだけに絞ってあり、これが抜群の操作性です。
まさに大空を自由に飛び回れます。
SEGAのナイツが360度自由に飛び回れたらこんな感じでしょうか。
扇風機で顔に風を当てながらプレイすると臨場感が増すのでオススメです。

舞台は人々がいなくなって動物たちが住み着いたフランスの主要都市。
ドキュメンタリー風の語りを聞きながらストーリーを追っていきます。
まだ全然途中なので結末は知りませんが、楽しみです。

今のところ個人的にVRでNo1の評価です。
知人にVR体験させるならまず見せたい作品。

author: {'steamid': '76561198056049121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1558664057}
review:
TL; DR: With a bad design making the game unplayable, Eagle Flight is one of a very tiny handful of games where I solidly regret purchasing it.

Price is outrageous.

UPlay is horrible. Ubisoft and other companies like EA represent everything wrong with how to be a game company.

However, the biggest thing keeping me from playing this game is the bad design I talk about above, which is this: the game has constant warnings that pop up every millisecond WHILE YOU ARE MID-AIR: "hey tilt your head to turn." Yeah, no shit, I am at full tilt and you should know this game, get rid of the messages, they break my immersion and they are going to make me puke. Can I at least have some settings to change their frequency, location or opacity?
In the settings, you cannot change these warnings in any way that I found, you cannot change their opacity, or their location, or their size....Nothing. You also cannot change the size or opacity of missions indicators, nor can you selectively turn them off. Lame. So as you fly around 2 things happen: your view is spammed and obstructed by all of the mission markers, breaking immersion and causing naseau, and you are also spammed by all of the warnings that certain missions cannot be started yet, and it tells you simply because you flew too near Notre Dame, for example. Not cool!
4. For a post-apoc game, this is the first one I ever played where it was dull and boring in 5 minutes, when just by reading the game description it should be a rad experience, as in pee-in-pants excitement.
5. This is what happens when AAA resources are outsourced to...ummm..malfunctioning robots programmed in a bizarre language full of nonsensical letters? This game is just horrible.

If the game would allow you to get rid of all the messages and indicators, then we would have a start. Just a start, mind you. Still a plethora of problematica.

Next, redesign the controls. You tilt your head, LT slows you, RT makes you go faster. That is it, that is the whole game. Wow, you gotta be kidding me! I twitch a finger or 2, and nod from time to time. Wow, call me an eagle! That is sooooo like an eagle!
So what? I am an eagle now, one who apparently does a lot of finger twitching and head leaning. Sigh. OK, look, did you guys even watch videos of what eagles do? Mating eagles lock talons and corkscrew dive. Wow cool, there is a whole level right there, mastering locking talons in a downward spiral dive at 100 to 200 mph. Sounds exciting to me! Eagles see in color brighter than us, plus they see UV light, and they can see an ant from a skyscraper; they have double binocular 340-degree vision, and mammal urine glows to their sensitive eyes. Could you have paid attention to none of the vision? I mean devs, they don't call a person with good vision as having "eagle vision" or "eagle eyes" just for fun. How could you not have known eagles have different eyes and why didn't that get put in the game either? The lack of research and proper attention to detail is so poor it is unimaginable, or at least it is for a AAA maker like Ubisoft.
Eagles do a lot more too than glide and catch gigantic fish. Eagles can swoop, dodge, do loop-de-loops, fight with their feet and beak, and guess what? EAGLES FLAP THEIR WINGS WHEN THEY FLY AND FOLD THEM WHEN THEY GO INTO A DIVE and for you to have an eagle game where you steer AND fly by tilting head, but you do not get to dive or flap your wings or even ride a thermal? Stupid. Poor. Shabby. 
I know it sounds crazy, but eagles also have these huge talons as well, kind of like having razor blades instead of fingernails. They use these "talons" to club or strike small birds while in a dive, and they can fight like demons with their claws, and they are one of the few animals outside of mammals that exhibit clear play behavior as adults, usually by tandem soaring or follow-the-leader, and of course ALL MID-AIR! So there should be several talon grip and talon slash attacks, for midair and ground swoops, and a head butt maneuver for mid-air stun kills on birds; there should be a glide method of flight, for long soars or thermal risers, and a flap method, where you flap your arms and go higher or faster; you could even do levels where you synchronize stunts and flights with other paired birds. Have it where if you fold your wings in on a dive you also go faster; I know those towers can register that I put the controls at my sides. That is part of the point of trackable wands in VR. Have the thumbpads control quick loop-de-loops, for dogfights and second-chance prey acquisition. So much potential wasted and ruined, it just isn't even worth playing at all. I hate on a lot of games, I know, but seldom do I ever regret buying them because the bad games make the good games all the more appreciated, and usually a bad game has at least something to offer.

However, this is Ubisoft, and I expected much more for the massive $20 I paid. This game is one of a very tiny handful of games where I solidly regret purchasing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000470818', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1490835684}
review:
Whether or not I reccomend Eagle Flight depends mostly on what you're looking for. If all you want is a VR toy, it's fantastic.  It's fairly immersive and the flight mechanics, while not as deep as I'd prefer, are intuitive and satisfying. The relationships between head position, view, and control are natural after only a few minutes, and highlight an aspect of VR I wouldn't have expected to work nearly as well as it does: With the right control scheme, a game can completely change the way you think about locomotion and navigation. Eagle Flight is the first VR experience I've gotten mild vertigo coming out of, as I'd grown to accept that tilting my head should produce a banking turn.

Unfortunately the game underneath isn't nearly as strong as the mechanics it's built on. Eagle Flight strongly resembles something like PilotWings in that respect, or some modern mobile games. It lacks the depth and substance I've come to expect from PC games, and left me particularly disappointed with regard to how much being an eagle specifically plays into things. Hunting and combat are present, but not in any way that resembles how actual birds accomplish such tasks, nor simplified in a manner that enhances gameplay. Combat manifests as a simple projectile shooter with a time limit, with actual gameplay resembling StarFox about as much as any actual eagle behavior. Hunting, similarly, is reduced to a collectathon given challenge only by tight time limits. This represents a lot of wasted potential, especially since the strenghts of the game (control and sensation) would have played very effectively into a more realistic, deeper system, and are somewhat wasted here.

The game plays very nicely, and given the fledgling nature of VR and comparison to other titles, the simplified, somewhat antiquated gameplay is forgivable. On those grounds I will reccomend it, especially if its on sale. That said, this is not a simulator in any respect, nor is the gameplay and progression at all organtic. There is fun to be had, but a finite amount of fun. The game is relatively short, and unless you're a perfectionist who likes hitting the top of scoreboards, you won't find much reason to stick around after the first few hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036598487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1641941157}
review:
A great showcase of what a triple A budget can do for a VR experience, Eagle Flight is a great game, and here's why. Upon starting the game, you're presented with a heavily styalised open world representation of Paris, set several decades after the end of humanity. This has resulted in the decay of the city with vegetation growing through buildings and exotic animals running loose through the streets. The style of the graphics looks great and the game runs flawlessly on my system. You play the role of a new born eagle facing the challenges of early life such as catching food and expanding your territory. The single player campaign then progresses as your eagle grows into adulthood with more and more difficult tasks such as fighting off crows and protecting your mate. Overall the campaign consists of 23 story missions each lasting 2-3 minutes to comples, and a lot longer to '3 star'. Accompanying these are several more challenging missions that unlock as you earn stars through the story missions. While the single player could be considered short, the open world nature of the game really allows it to become what you make it. Ubisoft have included collectibles in typical Ubisoft fashion, but it's fun to explore the city and find all of the hidden tunnels and landmarks.

Eagle Flight also has multiplayer, which takes the form of a fairly simple 4v4 'capture the flag' style game, where each team of eagles has to catch some prey and take it back to the nest first. There is no progression to the multiplayer which is unfourtunate as it takes away from the replayability of the title. Furthermore, the small playerbase can make it tricky to find a game sometimes. With that said, although simplistic, the multiplayer is good fun and I still go back to it every so often.

Readers who are prone to motion sickness, rejoice! I had no problems with the exhillarating flying motion in the game, and I have read that many other players have had few issues. Instead of turning your head to turn, which could get painful after a lengthy session, the game instructs you to tilt your head. This works great as it simulates how a bird tilts to turn and is much more ergonomic. The presence of your eagle's beak in the place of your nose also provides a stable point in your field of view that likely reduces motion discomfort, and the game has cleverly implimented subtle 'barn doors' that intrude on your view when turning particularly sharply.

Ubisoft have really impressed me with this title. In recent years, I have found their products to have been underperforming, unpolished, and often feel incomplete. While this is by no means a lengthy experience, it runs flawlessly, looks beautiful, and is probably one of the most complete VR experiences on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345667092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1483423303}
review:
This is a mixed review. 

I was eager to try a game from a big developer to see what they could do. Honestly, I was a little disappointed. If the pricetag was much lower, I would have felt less disappointed. There are a lot of great things about this game, but what I was hoping for, what I was expecting, was to actually feel like I'm flying. There are free VR experiences out there already that manage to do that, but something about this game can't seem to capture it. There is no feeling in the pit of your stomach like you've just left the ground. No exhiliration, no real sense of flight. From a big game company, I expected AAA graphics, and instead got something a little more cartoony, and far less realistic. I can appreciate the art style they were going for, but for the price they're asking, I demand more.

The narration and storytelling are great. I like the idea of moving your head to control your eagle. You do need a gamepad to play this game, though I don't understand why. A Vive controller could have worked just as well. 

I would pass on this game until the price comes down. It's simply not worth the money as it is now. I really like this developer, and I hope to see more titles come from them at a level of gaming I've grown to expect from them. VR is a new platform, yes, and some allowances need to be made while the industry figures out what's it's doing and how to make money with it, but with so many other VR titles out there that are providing amazing experiences for a fraction of the cost, I can't recommend this game.

review:
Initially, this was a very cathartic, enjoyable experience. The novelty of flying around is great, and it doesn't really ever wear off.

I also realize that I had ultimately purchased a game that relies heavily on multiplayer. One of the biggest draws for me was the cross-platform play. Yet, 20 minutes were collectively spent waiting for other players. Somehow, across all three platforms, there's simply nobody playing. To me, the uncertainty of player support is a pretty big risk when dropping $40. The long waits, only to be met with rather boring 1v1 matches was enough to deter me.

Note: Be weary of overzealous reviews. It seems the VR community enjoys overhyping things until the next best thing comes out. Polish and AAA quality don't mean anything in a multiplayer game if there's nobody playing it.

I was really excited to play this game because I love flying FPV Planes and Racing Quads.

Pros:
1) No motion sickness via the well placed turn "blinders".
2) The areas are well laid out with no hitbox issues.

Cons:
1) The controls are "floaty" by design. There is very little inertia in the flying. You are just directing the movement of a floating camera. Due to the lack of physics, my brain never believed it was flying, which is the biggest deal breaker for me. 
2) The head tilting controls feels like I'm going to give myself whiplash at high speeds.
